facts.text: This is Original Jurisdiction Petition No. 54 of 1953 under Article 32 of the Constitution for a writ in the nature of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 54 of 1953. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petition filed by Ham Narayan Singh on behalf of Dr. S. P. Mukerjee, Shri N. C. Chatterjee, Pandit Nandial Sharma and Pandit Guru Dutt Vaid, the real petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition for a writ of habeas companypus filed by one ham Narayan Singh on behalf of four gentlemen, namely, Dr. S. P. Mukerjee, Shri N. C. Chatterjee, Pandit Nandial Sharma and Pandit Guru Dutt Vaid, who are the real petitioners in the case.

facts.text: The four petitioners were arrested on the evening of 6th March 1953.

anchor.surface_text: These persons were arrested on the evening of the 6th March, 1953, and they are number being prosecuted for alleged defiance of an order prohibiting meetings and processions in the area in question, an offence punishable under section 188 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: The petitioners are being prosecuted for alleged defiance of an order prohibiting meetings and processions, offence under section 188 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: These persons were arrested on the evening of the 6th March, 1953, and they are number being prosecuted for alleged defiance of an order prohibiting meetings and processions in the area in question, an offence punishable under section 188 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Detention justified on basis of two remand orders: one by Mr. Dhillon, Additional District Magistrate, Delhi at about 8 p.m. on 6th March 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Their detention is sought to be justified on the basis of two remand orders, the one alleged to have been- passed by Mr. Dhillon, Additional District Magistrate, Delhi, at about 8 p. m. on the 6th March, 1953,

facts.text: Second remand order alleged by trying Magistrate at about 3 p.m. on 9th March 1953 while adjourning the case.

anchor.surface_text: and the other alleged to have been passed by the trying Magistrate at about 3 p. m. on the 9th March while adjourning the case on the representation made before him that a habeas pus petition was being moved in this Court.

facts.text: First remand order dated 6th March expired on 9th March and is no longer in force, conceded even assuming valid.

anchor.surface_text: but we companysider it unnecessary to enter upon a discussion of those questions, as it is number companyceded that the first order of remand dated the 6th March even assuming it was a valid one expired on the 9th March and is numberlonger in force.

facts.text: Trying Magistrate proceeding under section 344 CrPC, order must be in writing signed by presiding Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The trying Magistrate was obviously proceeding at that stage under section 344 of the Criminal Procedure Code, which requires him, if he chooses to adjourn the case pending before him, to remand by warrant the accused if in custody, and it goes on to provide Every order made under this section by a companyrt other than a High Court shall be in writing signed by the presiding Judge or Magistrate.

facts.text: This Court ordered on 10th March production of records before Additional District Magistrate and trying Magistrate together with remand papers.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Magistrate under this section was produced before us in companypliance with an order of this Court made on the 10th March, which directed the production in this Court as early as possible of the records before the Additional District Magistrate and the trying Magistrate together with the remand papers for inspection by Counsel for the petitioner.

facts.text: Order produced merely directs adjournment till 11th March, contains no direction for remanding accused to custody.

anchor.surface_text: The order produced merely directs the adjournment of the case till the 11th March and companytains numberdirection for, remanding the accused to custody till that date.

facts.text: Four slips of paper handed to Registrar at 5-20 p.m. last evening, purport to be warrants of detention dated 6th March addressed to Superintendent of Jail, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Last evening, four slips of paper were handed to the Registrar of this Court at 5-20 p. m. On one side they purport to be warrants of detention dated 6th March and addressed to the Superintendent of Jail, Delhi, directing the accused to be kept in judicial lock-up and to be produced in companyrt on the 9th March 1953.

facts.text: Slips contain on back endorsements: Remanded to judicial till 11th March 1953.

anchor.surface_text: These warrants companytain on their back the following endorsements Remanded to judicial till 11th March, 1953

facts.text: Slips not produced notwithstanding direction in order of 10th March.

anchor.surface_text: but they were number produced, numberwithstanding the clear direction companytained in our order of the 10th March.

facts.text: Court records produced do not contain any order of remand made on 9th March.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt records produced before us do number companytain any order of remand made on the 9th March.

facts.text: Solicitor-General explains slips were with police officer present in court yesterday, filed at 5-20 p.m. after court rose.

anchor.surface_text: The Solicitor-General appearing on behalf of the Government explains that these slips of paper,which would be of crucial importance to the case, were with a police officer who was present in companyrt yesterday, but after the Court rose in the evening the latter thought that their production might be of some importance and therefore they were filed before the Registrar at 5-20 p. m.

facts.text: Court cannot take notice of documents produced in such circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot take numberice of documents produced in such circumstances, and we are number satisfied that there was any order of remand companymitting the accused to further custody till the 11th March.

facts.text: No order of remand committing accused to custody till 11th March.

anchor.surface_text: and we are number satisfied that there was any order of remand companymitting the accused to further custody till the 11th March.

facts.text: In habeas corpus, regard to legality of detention at time of return, not institution.

anchor.surface_text: It has been held by this Court that in habeas companypus proceedings, the Court is to have regard to the legality or otherwise of the detention at the time of the return and number with reference to the institution of the proceedings.

facts.text: Material date is 10th March when affidavit on behalf of Government filed justifying detention.

anchor.surface_text: The material date on the facts of this case is the 10th March, when the affidavit on behalf of the Government was filed justifying the detention as a lawful one.

facts.text: On 10th March, there was no order remanding the four persons to custody.

anchor.surface_text: But the position, as we have stated, is that on that date there was numberorder remanding the four persons to custody.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Chief Justice Patanjali Sastri on March 12, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: 1953. March 12. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by the Chief Justice. PATANJALI SASTRI C. J.-This is a petition for a writ of habeas companypus filed by one ham Narayan Singh

facts.text: Counsel for petitioners: Jai Gopal Sethi, Veda Vyas, S. K. Kapur, A. K. Datt, N. Chona, B. Pathnaik, A. AT. Sinha.

issues.text: Whether the order of remand alleged to have been made by the trying Magistrate on the 9th March was valid under section 344 of the Criminal Procedure Code

anchor.surface_text: As regards the order of remand alleged to have been made by the trying Magistrate on the 9th March, the position is as follows-The trying Magistrate was obviously proceeding at that stage under section 344 of the Criminal Procedure Code, which requires him, if he chooses to adjourn the case pending before him, to remand by warrant the accused if in custody, and it goes on to provide Every order made under this section by a court other than a High Court shall be in writing signed by the presiding Judge or Magistrate. The order of the Magistrate under this section was produced before us in compliance with an order of this Court made on the 10th March

issues.text: Whether in habeas corpus proceedings the Court is to have regard to the legality or otherwise of the detention at the time of the return and not with reference to the institution of the proceedings

anchor.surface_text: It has been held by this Court that in habeas corpus proceedings, the Court is to have regard to the legality or otherwise of the detention at the time of the return and not with reference to the institution of the proceedings. The material date on the facts of this case is the 10th March, when the affidavit on behalf of the Government was filed justifying the detention as a lawful one.

issues.text: Whether there was any valid order remanding the petitioners to custody on the 10th March 1953 the date of return

anchor.surface_text: The material date on the facts of this case is the 10th March, when the affidavit on behalf of the Government was filed justifying the detention as a lawful one. But the position, as we have stated, is that on that date there was no order remanding the four persons to custody. anchor.surface_text: Various questions of law and fact have been argued before us by Mr. Sethi on behalf of the petitioner, but we consider it unnecessary to enter upon a discussion of those questions, as it is now conceded that the first order of remand dated the 6th March even assuming it was a valid one expired on the 9th March and is no longer in force.
